turn.text: I think it is important to keep in mind that we are talking about cutting off a back pay award, reducing back pay below the amount that would be needed to make victims of employment discrimination whole, and there has to be some reason for chopping off the award, not just reducing it by the amount of subsequent earnings or subsequent amounts that could have been earned, but chopping off the award at the date of the offer.
Now, there is some logic to doing that.
If the offer takes the form of saying, from now on, you will suffer no further the effects of the discrimination, then it makes sense to say, you will not--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you have to allege discrimination, don't you, because at this time it has not been determined whether there was or was not discrimination.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That's right, but of course the employer is not liable at all for any back pay if he is not found to have discriminated.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But before the determination both parties are kind of looking at their whole card, really.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, that's right.
That's right, but in that they are in the same position.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why shouldn't the Commission take the position as far as possible consistent with the statute, encourage mitigation of damages, encourage employees to cut liability, and encourage settlement?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: We absolutely do all three of those things, and if this had been an unreasonable decision by the employees, if they had been unemployed and had turned down a good job offer, that would be an unreasonable failure to mitigate damages.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is your final answer on the Chief Justice's question about a provisional offer?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: I think the offer has to be to place... and I think this is the Board rule.
The offer has to be to place them in the same position as other employees.
They can't be under a cloud--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So the answer is that that kind of offer would not suffice.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That sort of offer would not suffice, although, although they would be in no better position than other employees, and if they proved to be incompetent or unqualified, and that were a ground for dismissal, they could be dismissed subsequently.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Strauss... oh, excuse me.
Did you finish your answer?

I don't think you can phrase your test in terms of whether it is reasonable from the point of view of the employee, because in the example Justice White gave you, if there were no seniority system at Ford, and they were employed at General Motors, and very reasonably decided, well, I don't think I will take the Ford offer, you agree that would nevertheless cut off their back pay?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes, if Ford--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So it does not turn just on the reasonableness of the employee's decision.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That is back to the two principles.
The Labor Act principle is distinct from the mitigation principle.

The Labor Act principle says, if you are put in a position such that you will not continue to suffer the effects of the alleged discrimination, that cuts it off no matter how reasonable it was to take that job.

Then there is a separate way the employer can reduce his back pay, and that is by showing that the employee had a reasonable chance to take a job, whether or not that job was identical to the one he would have had had he not been discriminated against and he failed to do that.
Either of those avenues can be used by the employer to reduce back pay.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, we don't need to be bound by the Labor Board principle, I don't think.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: No, that's right.
In fact, the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And anyway, isn't that just some discrete application of a mitigation rule?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Well, it certainly serves the same policies as the mitigation rule, Justice White.
The reason I am distinguishing it so sharply is that I think analytically they rest on different foundations, and it is important to see the rationale of the Board rule.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why should the Labor Board rule be important in this context at all?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, I think it is not obvious that it should.
We are, as I said, accepting arguendo that it should because the remedial provision of Title VII--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what if it weren't?
Then how would we come out in this case?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Well, I certainly don't think--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Just on a straight mitigation.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --I certainly don't think there is any logical sense in cutting off the back pay award at a date if the employee continues to suffer injury after that date on account of the employer's discrimination.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You certainly would come out differently on your provisional offer.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, he continues to suffer the injury of being under the provisional cloud which he would not have been under.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I know, but he wouldn't continue to suffer if he won the lawsuit, but if he lost it, why should he continue to have his seniority that he didn't deserve in the first place?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, we are cutting off back pay, and we are saying, no back pay--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I know, but that is just the Labor Board rule.
Your only answer to the Chief Justice's question was the Labor Board rule.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Well, I agree, the provisional--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: On a mitigation theory, I can't imagine--

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --A provisional offer would... may well suffice to mitigate damages in certain circumstances.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --All right.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If you admit that, why, this is a provisional offer case, isn't it, because in effect they said, you get the job, and provided you win, you get everything else, too.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: I do think there is a possible mitigation argument in this case.
The problem is that both lower courts found it was reasonable for them to decline the Ford offer, and it is a reasonableness test.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Wester, do you have anything further?

turn.speaker: john_r_wester
turn.label: Mr. John R. Wester
turn.text: I would suggest that the reasonableness analysis employed in the mitigation cases to which Mr. Strauss has referred does not apply to this case, and the reason it does not apply is because the reasonableness analysis in those cases has always come from the context where the courts or the Board were evaluating whether a job other than the one that was the subject of the claim was being offered, and in this case, of course, it was the job that was the subject of the claim that was being offered.
All of the mitigation damages concerned interim or alternative employment other than, distinct from the job initially sought.
Except for that clarification, I shall be pleased to address any questions anyone might have of me.
Otherwise, I shall waive the remainder of our allotted time.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The honorable Court is now adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.
